Our expos√© of the Ohio derailment disaster is generating national attention, with our new video on the matter racking up more than a million views. Please click here to watch and share it further.

We‚Äôre still digging into the issue, but in the meantime, we‚Äôre bringing you other stories of corporate and political malfeasance. For example, in today‚Äôs featured story, in full below, we look at how fossil fuel interests are working with politicians from both parties to valorize natural gas as a ‚Äúgreen energy‚Äù ‚Äî and this pro-gas pep squad includes Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine (R).

Also:

  • Today at 1PM ET is our weekly Callin show Lever Live. This week, David Sirota is joined by the Lever reporters who wrote our blockbuster report on this past weekend‚Äôs train derailment and ensuing controlled chemical release in East Palestine, Ohio. They‚Äôll also be taking questions from the audience LIVE on-air. To access the show, click here at 1pm ET.

sections: Last month, Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine (R)
to call natural gas a "green energy." The law was pushed by conservative dark money groups and passed by Republican lawmakers backed by the oil and gas industry.

A few weeks later, former congressman and 2022 Ohio Democratic Senate candidate Tim Ryan joined a fossil fuel front group that claims ‚Äúnatural gas is accelerating our transition to a clean energy future.‚Äù

These greenwashing efforts are examples of how politicians from both parties are helping the fossil fuel industry‚Äôs campaign to promote the use of natural gas and brand it as a climate-friendly energy source. At times, this help has entailed former elected officials getting hired by the industry.

The efforts come as the Biden administration considers banning gas stoves, based on concerns about asthma. Some cities have banned natural gas hookups in new buildings, while others are considering a ban.

Despite the claims of the energy industry and their political allies that natural gas is a climate-friendly alternative to other fossil fuels, the production and use of natural gas, which is essentially methane, has a negative impact on both the planet and public health. Natural gas, which people use to heat their homes and power their stoves, contributes to increasing global temperatures. Experts
the effects of natural gas leaks could make its use even worse for the planet than coal.
The American Gas Association, a gas industry lobbying group, has
natural gas as ‚Äúthe earth‚Äôs cleanest traditional fuel,‚Äù claiming that its use cuts emissions. Oil and gas giant ExxonMobil‚Äôs website
natural gas a cleaner fuel, while Chevron
it‚Äôs the ‚Äú‚Äã‚Äãcleanest burning conventional fuel.‚Äù Other companies
the idea of ‚Äúgreen‚Äù liquified natural gas, the form in which gas is stored and transported. In 2019, the Trump Administration even tried to

that methane is worse for the environment than fossil fuel companies let on. Methane molecules, the main component of natural gas, are as much as 90 times more effective at trapping heat than carbon dioxide molecules are. While methane releases far less carbon than coal, its use contributes to rising global temperatures.
the amount of methane they are leaking into the atmosphere. Researchers
that the effects of methane leaks during the fracking and transportation process could outweigh the supposed climate benefits of using natural gas over coal.

In addition to the broader climate impacts, there are also health and safety risks associated with using gas appliances in homes and workplaces. These factors have led some cities ‚Äî and some state and federal policymakers ‚Äî to look to move away from natural gas.

, California, have banned natural gas hookups in new buildings. The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission, a federal government agency that assesses risks associated with products and creates bans or recalls, is
In New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul (D) recently voiced her
for a ban on the use of fossil fuels for heating beginning in 2030. She also said she supported a ban on gas stoves in new construction. Last year, New York City
fossil fuel heating equipment in certain buildings starting in 2024.

The gas stove ban floated by the Biden administration quickly drew ire from conservatives concerned about a purported lack of personal freedom. Coal magnate Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) have now
legislation to preemptively block any federal ban on new gas stoves.
In many states, politicians have also already stepped in to protect the gas industry. In 2019, Flagstaff, Arizona, was
as a way to reduce emissions. The next year, the state legislature passed a preemption law barring cities and towns from banning natural gas on a local level.
and made it so cities and towns cannot ban natural gas ‚Äî often with backing from the fossil fuel industry. For instance, former Utah state Rep. Steve Handy (R)
, an initiative of The Pew Charitable Trusts, that gas utility Dominion Energy requested that he propose legislation barring natural gas bans, which he sponsored and
In Ohio, energy companies hold a notoriously strong influence. In 2020, the chair of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio
after electric utility FirstEnergy Corp allegedly
Ohio lobbyists and political officials to try to get a $1.3 billion buyout for two Ohio power plants.
through a dark money group to former Ohio House Speaker Larry Householder (R) and other politicians in exchange for the bailout. A federal corruption trial is underway.

There was also a dark money campaign behind the effort to develop and pass Ohio‚Äôs new law enshrining natural gas as a ‚Äúclean energy.‚Äù Ohio lawmakers passed the legislation as part of a collaboration with dark money groups tied to the fossil fuel industry, according to documents
by the Energy and Policy Institute, a watchdog group focusing on renewable energ,.
The documents show one of the bill‚Äôs cosponsors, Ohio state Sen. George Lang (R),

from a conference held last summer by the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC), a dark money group and policy hub for conservative politicians, that he would ‚Äúbe leaving the ALEC convention with some model legislation to define on the ORC [Ohio revised code] that natural gas is clean energy.‚Äù

One recipient of Lang‚Äôs email was Tom Rastin, executive vice president at the Ariel Corporation, the largest producer of natural gas compressors in the world. Natural gas compressors are crucial to pipelines because they make the gas easier to transport.

Rastin and his wife, Ariel CEO Karen Buchwald Wright, lead the Empowerment Alliance, a dark money group that supported the Ohio bill characterizing natural gas as clean energy. The couple has given money to the Republican Governors‚Äô Association, which bankrolled ads

, the Empowerment Alliance details its energy agenda. The first point is to ‚Äúrecognize natural gas as green.‚Äù They write: ‚ÄúAmerican natural gas is affordable, clean, abundant, and reliable energy that improves the environment while securing American energy independence.‚Äù
Emails show Rastin corresponding with Lang as well as state Sen. Mark Romanchuk (R), another sponsor. Romanchuk has publicly claimed the bill was
to call natural gas "sustainable" in some instances.
obtained by the Energy and Policy Institute, in October 2022, Romanchuk‚Äôs office sent language from the bill at least three times to Adam Hewitt, a
Dave Anderson, policy and communications manager for the Energy and Policy Institute,

: ‚ÄúWhat the emails reveal is just how closely Ohio lawmakers coordinated with a natural gas industry group on the new law that misleadingly defines methane gas as green energy, as the first step of a plan to introduce similar legislation in multiple states.‚Äù
DeWine, Ohio‚Äôs Republican governor, has taken
from several utilities that rely on or distribute natural gas, including American Electric Power, Duke Energy, NiSource, Dominion Energy, and FirstEnergy.

‚ÄúWe reviewed the ‚ÄòGreen Energy‚Äô language, and it has no effect on any state funding or regulations. The language is merely an opinion of the Ohio General Assembly,‚Äù Dan Tierney, DeWine‚Äôs press secretary, told
A prominent Ohio Democrat, meanwhile, is now aiding a separate fossil fuel industry campaign to greenwash natural gas.
Former congressman Tim Ryan, who lost the Ohio Senate race to J.D. Vance in November, recently
the leadership council of Natural Allies for a Clean Energy Future, a
‚ÄúI am excited to join Natural Allies and promote the role natural gas plays in meeting global climate goals faster, while advancing reliability and affordability here at home,‚Äù Ryan said in a

. ‚ÄúThese are kitchen table issues voters understand ‚Äî people‚Äôs livelihoods and jobs often depend on rational energy policy. As Democrats, we can be pro-climate, pro-affordability, and pro-natural gas.‚Äù
During his Senate campaign, Ryan told the

that fracking, a process commonly used to extract natural gas, has ‚Äúprovided enormous economic benefits and moved the U.S. towards energy independence. However, we need to significantly ramp up our oversight and regulation of the industry and its practices, especially in regard to its use and disposal of water, as well as methane leaks.‚Äù
narrated by young people that claims, ‚ÄúReplacing coal with natural gas is the best way to cut emissions, reach climate goals, [and] empower our future reliably, cleanly, and affordably.‚Äù
Ryan joined former Sen. Mary Landrieu (D-La.) on Natural Allies‚Äô leadership council. Landrieu, a conservative Democrat, became a
after losing her race in the 2014 election. She recently
to lobby for the Williams Companies, a natural gas company
Natural Allies, on pipeline issues. Landrieu has also
to help the oil and gas firm Enterprise Products obtain authorization to build a crude oil export hub off the coast of Texas.
